video.title: Death's Door and The Forgotten City (Zero Punctuation)

captions.text:
Man, looking for indie games worth reviewing 
is like that one Monty Python sketch sometimes.

We&#39;ve got Soulslike. Egg and Soulslike. 
Bacon and Soulslike. Soulslike, egg,

sausage and soulslike. And isometric hack and 
slash exploration games with RPG elements and

Soulslike. Death&#39;s Door being an example of that 
last one. In Death&#39;s Door, you play a little crow

who is one of many crows employed by some kind of 
celestial bureaucracy, and your job is to venture

into the world and capture the souls of the newly 
dead, who are generally newly dead because you

just killed the absolute motherfuck out of them, 
but that&#39;s quotas for you. After your latest

assignment gets stolen from you, you find yourself 
having to travel to the, erm, three corners of the

earth to harvest powerful souls from big bosses 
in order to open the titular Death&#39;s Door and

complete your assignment. And no, you can&#39;t fly 
there, despite being a bird. You probably can&#39;t

fly &#39;cos you&#39;re carrying the weight of a great big 
sword to do all the hacking and the slashing with.

I think this is that &quot;min-maxing&quot; thing people 
always go on about. Anyway, Death&#39;s Door is a game

I would classify as story rich and cash poor.
It&#39;s built a nice little world to take place in,

it&#39;s got that very indie-game art style you 
see in games like Ashen where it looks like

everything&#39;s made of folded craft paper. There&#39;s 
some fun dialogue to be had with interesting NPCs

who have that Dark Souls quality of adding 
life and texture to the setting while being

absolutely no bloody help whatsoever. It&#39;s 
just I find the gameplay to be generally a

bit flimsy. Part of that might be the isometric 
look, which I think might be becoming one of my

least favourite graphical styles, at least for 
action games. It makes it hard to gauge depth, the

characters are so tiny on screen you can&#39;t read 
the slogans on their hilarious souvenir T-shirts,

and it&#39;s too easy to get lost when the areas go 
past a certain size. In a third person open world

game if I&#39;m trying to remember where the tower of 
bollock scraping was I can look to the horizon for

its telltale spherical ramparts, but in isometric 
land I can only go &quot;Oh it was somewhere in the

easterly quadrant of this giant sheet of graph 
paper I can only see ten square yards of at

a time.&quot; And Death&#39;s Door doesn&#39;t have a map 
so no bollocks are getting scraped today.

The environments just feel like competing 
labyrinths with different wallpaper and

whenever I picked up a new ability that opened 
new areas I&#39;d be like &quot;Well, I did once see an

area I needed this ability to get to. I also once 
found a coffee place in Melbourne that did amazing

croissant french toast and I&#39;m fucked if I can 
remember where that was, too.&quot; So I felt very

disinclined to go hunting for optional secrets or 
extra weapons, especially since I plowed through

all the story bosses with very little trouble 
using nothing but one of the first weapons you

get in the game, because the combat&#39;s the other 
thing that&#39;s a bit flimsy. You can mash attack or

you can dodge or you can use a ranged attack and 
granted it&#39;s impressive for a flightless bird to

have any repertoire that goes beyond &quot;eat seed&quot; 
and &quot;hop about&quot; but it&#39;s not the most nuanced

gameplay in the world. All in all, probably for 
the best that Death&#39;s Door doesn&#39;t outstay its

welcome. I mean, just three big bosses to find 
and then back here for the inevitable plot twist

and dramatic climax, sure, I can rattle that out 
in one shift and be home in time for Thundercats.

So that&#39;s Death&#39;s Door. The Soulslike equivalent 
of a packet of Monster Munch. Some interesting

flavour to it but I&#39;ll stop thinking about it the 
moment it stops troubling my digestive system.

So the next game I tried out was The Forgettable 
Title. Oh sorry I meant The Forgotten City,

a sort of thinky thinky talky talky investigative 
adventure game thing that didn&#39;t get off on the

best foot with its name and playing like something 
that got hacked off a reject Bethesda game

complete with the traditional very off-putting 
fixed boggle eye contact conversations,

and with looking like it was pieced together 
from the example art that came free with the

3D modelling software, but somehow it drew me 
in. The premise is, you&#39;re a generic present day

chucklefuck who&#39;s too busy staring at their 
modern gizmo to avoid falling down a time

portal to 2000 years ago where a group of Ancient 
Romans are trapped in an underground city ruled

over by a central doctrine that if any of them 
commit a single sin, then all of them will die.

And if you&#39;re anything like me once this has been 
explained to you by the city&#39;s overseer you&#39;ll go

&quot;Whatever, grandad,&quot; forget this isn&#39;t Skyrim and 
immediately loot some coins out of the chest in

his bedroom. Whereupon a spooky voice will 
loudly denounce your sin and unsettle your

entire breakfast, and you&#39;ll be forced to 
sprint back to the time portal as the world

falls apart about your ears and half-digested 
pop tarts tumble down your legs. Then you get

teleported back to the start of the same day.
Yes, you&#39;re stuck in a time loop. Jolly original

idea if it weren&#39;t for Outer Wilds. And Sexy 
Brutale. And Elsinore. And Minit and all the

other ones. Bit of a trend in adventure games 
right now, actually, why only recently I don&#39;t

know seeing as Majora&#39;s Mask did it twenty 
years ago, but it&#39;s a good idea, it means

you can have a sense of ticking clock urgency 
while also not punishing the player for taking

their time to experiment and maybe occasionally 
blow off the main quest to flick playing cards

at Andie McDowell, film reference. So it might 
not be original and it might have the general

air of a basically okay-looking IKEA bookshelf 
that wobbles ominously when you lean on it,

but I think the writing carries The Forgotten 
City. From the initial quest to figure out which

of the twenty-odd boggle-eyed ancient Romans 
is going to fuck things up for everyone else

we delve into a deeper investigation of the city&#39;s 
true nature. The premise raises many philosophical

questions, very few of which go unaddressed 
in dialogue at some point - what constitutes

a sin? No one knows. How do they even know that 
committing a sin will kill them all? They don&#39;t,

that&#39;s why half the population are sitting on 
undisguised hate boners for the city&#39;s ruler.

When your game is heavily dialogue-tree focussed 
the important thing is that I should never feel

like I can&#39;t say something I want to say, 
and Forgotten City mostly pulls that off,

I&#39;m generally free to call out the 
local cunts for their various cunty

behaviours. So despite the wobbly design and 
occasional highly out of place combat section,

I stuck with Forgotten City. There was always an 
investigative thread to pull and a few to keep in

mind to pull in slightly different ways next time 
around and I was interested to see where it led.

I do wonder if the game would&#39;ve been more 
interesting if I didn&#39;t keep my entire inventory

from loop to loop. If I was obliged to remember 
sequences of actions required to get certain key

items before I could proceed the game might have 
had a more meaty challenge aspect to it. As it is,

success becomes inevitable. There&#39;s one sidequest 
centring around a merchant who&#39;s demanding a

thousand Denarii for an essential cure, but I&#39;d 
been swindling him out of five thousand Denarii

every loop for the last three so I just 
chucked the smug asshole some pocket change,

pausing only to wipe my nose with it. The 
hilarious thing is that there was a time

traveller before you who went through the loop 
enough times to grow old and die without finding

a solution. What the fuck was that guy doing? 
Trying to take his pet glacier for a walk?
